entry.title: Minnesota hit with first frigid temps of winter
entry.summary: Frigid temperatures blanketed Minnesota early Christmas week but some hardy Minnesotans still hit the slopes at Afton Alps on Christmas day.
entry.content:
Frigid temperatures blanketed Minnesota early Christmas week but some hardy Minnesotans still hit the slopes at Afton Alps on Christmas day.
David Joles – Star Tribune

Gallery: Kelly Richards, left, and Lisa Rippe, wore winter on their faces as they jogged around Lake Harriet in the sub-zero temps Wednesday, Dec. 27, 2017, in Minneapolis, MN. Richards, originally from the Twin Cities but who now lives in Texas and was visiting for the holidays, remarked to nearby walkers that the weather was great. Rippe chimed in, “If you are a penguin.”

entry.title: Sanford Health getting bigger in weight loss with Twin Cities stores opening
entry.summary: Sanford Health of South Dakota will offer counseling, food at several spots in the Twin Cities.
entry.content:
Sanford Health of South Dakota will offer counseling, food at several spots in the Twin Cities.

By Christopher Snowbeck Star Tribune
Brian Peterson - Star Tribune
A fast-growing chain of weight-loss centers from Sioux Falls-based Sanford Health has landed in the Twin Cities, with one store in Eden Prairie already open and five more locations expected in a year or so. Sanford Health, which is a big operator of hospitals and clinics in the Dakotas and Western Minnesota, currently has 35 weight-loss stores in 11 states, including some that are run by franchisees.

entry.title: Canadian Pacific Holiday Train makes a stop in Minnesota
entry.summary: Anticipation cut through the frigid winter air as crowds huddled together in Hastings, waiting for the 2017 Canadian Pacific Holiday Train to arrive. The event showcases the train, which is lit from engine to caboose, and also stages musical performances. Since 1999, Holiday Train shows have traveled across Canada and the northern United States, spreading cheer and raising funds and healthy food donations for local food shelves.

entry.title: Trump administration reversal on mining leases near BWCA is no surprise
entry.summary: U.S. Rep. Erik Paulsen understands the risks and should lead protection effort.
entry.content:
U.S. Rep. Erik Paulsen understands the risks and should lead protection effort.

By Editorial Board Star Tribune
AARON LAVINSKY • Star Tribune file
Ely environmental activist Becky Rom was photographed in 2016 on the edge of Birch Lake, the proposed site of a Twin Metals copper mine near northeastern Minnesota’s Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness. She led a lobbying campaign to convince outgoing Obama administration officials to reject a Chilean-owned mining company’s request to renew two mining leases on federally owned land near the BWCA. Last week, the U.S. Department of the Interior rejected the legal basis for denying the two leases, paving the way for federal officials to grant the leases.

entry.title: Super Bowl planners ready to help visitors navigate the Minneapolis skyways
entry.summary: Planners for the big event are readying an army of volunteer guides and a specially designed phone navigation app.
entry.content:
Planners for the big event are readying an army of volunteer guides and a specially designed phone navigation app.

By John Reinan Star Tribune
John Reinan

Gallery: The underground passage to Minneapolis City Hall feels like the tunnel storm troopers would be herding you down in a dystopian sci-fi movie.

John Reinan

Gallery: Now this is how you do it. The skyway in the Wells Fargo towers features photo murals depicting the history of downtown Minneapolis.

John Reinan

Gallery: This sign lends little cheer to an already-bleak backwater in the system.

John Reinan

Gallery: Many building owners have added attractive lobby areas, such as this one outside Penny’s coffee shop at 100 Washington Square.

John Reinan

Gallery: From here on, you’re out in the cold. A northern branch of the system ends at the Churchill apartment building.

John Reinan

Gallery: The owners of the Nic on 5th tower preserved a memory of the department store that once stood there.

John Reinan

Gallery: The recently renovated Fifth Street Towers lobby provides a large and welcoming public space.

John Reinan

Gallery: An abrupt dead end at Xcel Energy, where your only choices are to turn back or go outside.

John Reinan

Gallery: Many of the older buildings in the skyway system offer beautiful details, if you slow down to take a look.

John Reinan

Gallery: A walker in the skyway near Target Field.

John Reinan

Gallery: To see the magnificent lobby of Butler Square, you need to take a short exit ramp off the skyway.

John Reinan

Gallery: Sasquatch greets visitors to the Jack Link’s shop in Target Center.

John Reinan

Gallery: There are usually a few musicians performing in the skyways, especially in the winter.

John Reinan

Gallery: And finally, the heart of the skyway system, the place most people say is their favorite spot: the Crystal Court at IDS Center.

entry.title: A quick tour of the Minneapolis skyway system
entry.summary: The sprawling Minneapolis skyway system contains nearly 9 miles of enclosed walkways winding through downtown.
entry.content:
The sprawling Minneapolis skyway system contains nearly 9 miles of enclosed walkways winding through downtown.
John Reinan

Gallery: The underground passage to Minneapolis City Hall feels like the tunnel storm troopers would be herding you down in a dystopian sci-fi movie.

John Reinan

Gallery: Now this is how you do it. The skyway in the Wells Fargo towers features photo murals depicting the history of downtown Minneapolis.

John Reinan

Gallery: This sign lends little cheer to an already-bleak backwater in the system.

John Reinan

Gallery: Many building owners have added attractive lobby areas, such as this one outside Penny’s coffee shop at 100 Washington Square.

John Reinan

Gallery: From here on, you’re out in the cold. A northern branch of the system ends at the Churchill apartment building.

John Reinan

Gallery: The owners of the Nic on 5th tower preserved a memory of the department store that once stood there.

John Reinan

Gallery: The recently renovated Fifth Street Towers lobby provides a large and welcoming public space.

John Reinan

Gallery: An abrupt dead end at Xcel Energy, where your only choices are to turn back or go outside.

John Reinan

Gallery: Many of the older buildings in the skyway system offer beautiful details, if you slow down to take a look.

John Reinan

Gallery: A walker in the skyway near Target Field.

John Reinan

Gallery: To see the magnificent lobby of Butler Square, you need to take a short exit ramp off the skyway.

John Reinan

Gallery: Sasquatch greets visitors to the Jack Link’s shop in Target Center.

John Reinan

Gallery: There are usually a few musicians performing in the skyways, especially in the winter.

John Reinan

Gallery: And finally, the heart of the skyway system, the place most people say is their favorite spot: the Crystal Court at IDS Center.

entry.title: Minnesota music scene’s best moments and 10 best albums in 2017
entry.content:
JEFF WHEELER • jeff.wheeler@startribune.com
Jeremy Messersmith brought relentlessly upbeat music to Powderhorn Park and other venues in free concerts in which people were invited to join in. Jeremy Messersmith launched The Best Road Trip Ever! Micro Tour Monday morning with a concert in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis and then one in Mears Park in St. Paul. The tour, which will have at least 50 shows, is in support of the album he dropped a week ago, 11 Obscenely Optimistic Songs For Ukulele: A Micro-Folk Record For The 21st Century And Beyond. The new songbook and album, he notes on his website, is “jam-packed with ridiculous songs about kittens, world peace, flying cars and the transformative power of love.”
